definitions: elementary school providing basic education for young children typically aged five to eleven
preliminary election where party members vote to choose candidates for general election
examples: The local primary has an excellent reputation for early childhood education
My daughter will start primary school next September
Voter turnout for the Democratic primary exceeded all expectations
She won the primary by a significant margin of votes

definitions: member of the biological order including humans, apes, monkeys, and lemurs characterized by flexible hands and complex behavior
senior bishop or archbishop who heads an ecclesiastical province or national church
examples: Chimpanzees are highly intelligent primates that use tools in nature
The zoo's primate exhibit features several species of monkeys and apes
The Archbishop of Canterbury serves as primate of the Anglican Church
The primate presided over the national synod meeting yesterday

definitions: period of greatest strength, vigor, success, or influence in someone's life
positive integer divisible only by itself and one without remainder
state or time of highest quality, value, or perfection
examples: Athletes typically reach their prime in their late twenties
The company flourished during its prime years of innovation
Seven is a prime number with no divisors except one and seven
Mathematicians study the distribution of prime numbers in sequences
This restaurant serves prime cuts of aged beef
The property occupies a prime location downtown

definitions: elementary textbook that introduces basic principles of a subject to beginners
base coat of paint applied before the main coat to improve adhesion
small explosive charge that ignites the main propellant in ammunition
examples: This biology primer covers all the fundamental concepts clearly
Students should read the primer before attending advanced lectures
Apply primer to the walls before painting them with color
The metal surfaces need special primer to prevent rust
The ammunition's primer failed to ignite the gunpowder charge
Modern cartridges use reliable primers for consistent firing

definitions: process of preparing a surface for painting by applying primer coat
psychological phenomenon where exposure to stimulus influences response to subsequent stimulus
examples: Proper priming ensures the paint adheres well to surfaces
The contractor spent two days priming all the interior walls
Semantic priming affects how quickly people recognize related words
The study examined priming effects on decision-making behavior

definitions: person belonging to preliterate, nonindustrial society or early stage of cultural development
fundamental or basic element from which more complex things are constructed
artwork created in deliberately simple style reminiscent of early art forms
examples: Early primitives developed basic tools from stone and bone
Anthropologists study how primitives organized their social structures
These graphical primitives form the basis of complex designs
Programming languages provide primitives for basic operations
The gallery specializes in American primitives from the nineteenth century
Her paintings have a primitive quality that appeals to collectors

definitions: small perennial plant with pale yellow flowers that bloom in early spring
examples: Wild primroses carpet the woodland floor each April
She planted primroses along the garden path for spring color

definitions: male member of a royal family other than the sovereign
son of a monarch or sovereign ruler
outstanding leader or foremost person in a particular field or group
examples: The prince attended the state dinner in formal military uniform
Several European princes gathered for the royal wedding ceremony
The king's eldest son holds the title Prince of Wales
The young prince will inherit the throne upon his father's death
He's considered a prince among conductors in classical music
The business mogul was a prince of the financial industry

definitions: head administrator of an elementary, middle, or high school responsible for overall management
original sum of money invested or loaned, excluding interest or profits
leading performer in a concert, play, opera, or ballet company
examples: The principal announced new safety protocols at the assembly
Parents met with the principal to discuss curriculum changes
The loan's principal amount was fifty thousand dollars
She pays extra toward the principal to reduce interest charges
The ballet's principal dancers rehearsed their pas de deux
She was promoted to principal cellist in the orchestra

definitions: territory ruled by a prince or from which a prince takes his title
order of angels in Christian celestial hierarchy ranking above archangels
examples: Monaco remains one of Europe's few surviving principalities today
The medieval principality controlled important trade routes
According to theology, principalities are the third angelic order
The principalities govern nations and guide their leaders spiritually

definitions: fundamental truth or proposition serving as foundation for belief or action
rule of personal conduct based on moral or ethical standards
fundamental scientific law or assumption from which others are derived
examples: The principle of equality underlies our democratic system
These design principles guide all our architectural decisions
She refused to compromise her principles for financial gain
Acting on principle, he returned the wallet with all money
The principle of conservation of energy governs physical systems
Archimedes' principle explains why objects float in water

definitions: text or images produced by printing process on paper or other material
picture or design made from pressing inked surface onto paper or fabric
decorative pattern or design applied to fabric or clothing material
examples: The print was too small for elderly readers to see
This book went out of print twenty years ago
The museum acquired several original Warhol prints last year
She makes limited edition prints of her watercolor paintings
Her dress featured a bold floral print in bright colors
The designer's new collection showcases geometric prints

definitions: electronic device that produces text or images on paper from digital input
person or company whose business is printing books, newspapers, or other materials
examples: The office printer ran out of toner during the presentation
She connected her laptop to the wireless printer
The printer delivered five thousand copies of the new catalog
Local printers competed for the lucrative government contract

definitions: process or business of producing books, newspapers, or other printed materials
total number of copies of a book or publication produced at one time
method or technique used to transfer ink or design onto surfaces
examples: The printing of the dictionary took several months to complete
Digital printing has revolutionized the publishing industry
The first printing sold out within three days of release
They ordered a second printing of ten thousand copies
Screen printing works well for t-shirt designs
The artist specializes in woodblock printing techniques

definitions: artist who creates prints using techniques like etching, lithography, or screen printing
examples: The printmaker demonstrated traditional etching techniques at the workshop
Several renowned printmakers exhibited their work at the gallery

definitions: artistic process of creating prints through various techniques including etching, lithography, and screen printing
examples: She studied printmaking at the School of Visual Arts
The museum offers printmaking workshops for beginners every Saturday

definitions: head of a religious house or order ranking below an abbot
examples: The prior managed the monastery's daily operations and finances
Brother Thomas was elected prior by the monastic community

definitions: state of being regarded as more important than others and treated accordingly
thing that is regarded as more important than others and requiring attention
examples: Emergency vehicles have priority at all traffic intersections
Customer satisfaction takes priority over short-term profits
Finding affordable housing is our top priority this year
The government made education reform a national priority

definitions: transparent optical element with flat polished surfaces that refracts light
solid geometric figure with two parallel polygonal ends and rectangular sides
particular perspective or framework through which something is viewed or analyzed
examples: The prism split white light into rainbow colors
Scientists use prisms to analyze light spectra from stars
Calculate the volume of a triangular prism with given dimensions
The crystal formed a perfect hexagonal prism shape
We must examine this issue through the prism of social justice
Historical events look different through the prism of modern values

definitions: building where people are legally held as punishment for crimes or while awaiting trial
situation or relationship that severely restricts someone's freedom or happiness
examples: The new prison houses over two thousand inmates
He served five years in federal prison for fraud
Her marriage had become a prison she desperately wanted to escape
The job felt like a prison with no opportunity for growth

definitions: person legally held in prison as punishment for crimes or while awaiting trial
person captured and held by enemy forces during war or conflict
person trapped by circumstances or unable to escape a situation
examples: The prisoner was granted parole after serving ten years
Prisoners have access to educational programs and library services
The Geneva Convention protects the rights of prisoners of war
Enemy forces released all prisoners after the ceasefire agreement
She felt like a prisoner in her own home
He was a prisoner of his past mistakes

definitions: state of being free from public attention or unsanctioned intrusion
ability to control access to one's personal information and activities
examples: The celebrity struggled to maintain privacy despite media attention
They moved to the countryside seeking more privacy
Digital privacy concerns have increased with social media use
The company updated its privacy policy to protect user data

definitions: soldier of the lowest rank in the army or marines
examples: The private completed basic training at Fort Benning
She was promoted from private to private first class

definitions: transfer of business, industry, or service from public to private ownership and control
examples: The privatisation of the railway system sparked public debate
Critics argued privatisation would reduce service quality

definitions: transfer of business, industry, or service from public to private ownership and control
examples: The privatization plan included selling state-owned telecommunications companies
Privatization of utilities led to increased competition

definitions: special right, advantage, or immunity granted to a particular person or group
legal right to refuse to disclose confidential communications in legal proceedings
examples: Wealthy students enjoy privileges that others cannot afford
Club membership includes the privilege of using exclusive facilities
Attorney-client privilege protects confidential legal communications
The journalist invoked privilege to protect her sources

definitions: reward given to winner of competition, contest, or recognition of achievement
something of great value that is highly desired or worth striving for
examples: She won first prize in the national science competition
The Nobel Prize recognizes exceptional contributions to humanity
The rare manuscript was the prize of his book collection
The championship trophy became their most prized possession

definitions: professional boxer who fights in matches for monetary prizes
examples: The prizefighter trained six hours daily for the championship bout
Many prizefighters came from working-class backgrounds seeking fortune

definitions: professional athlete who competes for money rather than as amateur
person with professional expertise or exceptional skill in particular activity
argument or consideration in favor of something being discussed
examples: She turned pro after winning three amateur championships
The tennis pro earned millions in tournament prizes
He's a real pro at negotiating complex business deals
Call a pro to fix the plumbing rather than attempting it yourself
Let's list the pros and cons before making our decision
One major pro of remote work is eliminating commute time

definitions: extent to which something is likely to happen or be the case
mathematical expression of the likelihood of an event occurring as a ratio
examples: The probability of rain tomorrow is seventy percent
There's a high probability the project will finish on time
Calculate the probability of drawing two aces from a deck
The probability of rolling a six is one-sixth

definitions: person or thing likely to be chosen or to achieve something
examples: She's a probable for the Olympic team next year
The coach listed five probables for the starting lineup

definitions: legal process of proving validity of a will and administering deceased estate
official proving of a will as authentic by the probate court
examples: The estate is currently in probate awaiting distribution
Probate proceedings can take months or even years to complete
The lawyer filed the will for probate immediately
The court granted probate after verifying the document's authenticity

definitions: court-ordered period of supervised release instead of imprisonment for offenders
period of testing or observing character or abilities before permanent acceptance
examples: He received two years probation instead of jail time
Violating probation terms could result in immediate imprisonment
New employees undergo a three-month probation before permanent hiring
Her probation period at the firm ends next week

definitions: device used to physically explore or examine something, especially electronically
unmanned spacecraft designed to explore space and transmit data
thin medical instrument for exploring wounds or body cavities
thorough investigation or inquiry into a matter
examples: The technician used an electronic probe to test circuit connections
Temperature probes monitor the reactor core continuously
NASA launched a probe to study Jupiter's moons
The Mars probe sent back stunning images of the planet's surface
The surgeon used a probe to examine the wound depth
Dental probes help detect cavities in teeth
The congressional probe into corruption lasted six months
Journalists conducted a probe into the company's financial practices

definitions: matter or situation regarded as unwelcome or harmful and needing to be overcome
mathematical question or puzzle requiring solution through calculation or reasoning
examples: Traffic congestion has become a serious problem downtown
We need to address this problem before it gets worse
Students solved complex algebra problems during the exam
This geometry problem requires applying the Pythagorean theorem

definitions: established or official way of doing something through a series of actions
medical operation or treatment involving a series of steps
examples: Follow the safety procedure when operating heavy machinery
The company updated its hiring procedures last month
The surgical procedure takes approximately two hours
She underwent a minor procedure to remove the cyst

definitions: action or series of actions conducted in order to achieve a particular result
examples: The proceeding took longer than anyone anticipated
We observed the whole proceeding from start to finish

definitions: legal action or process conducted in a court of law
published report of a set of meetings or conference
series of events or activities happening in formal or public context
examples: The court proceedings were broadcast live on television
Divorce proceedings can be emotionally and financially draining
The conference proceedings will be published next month
She contributed a paper to the proceedings of the symposium
The graduation proceedings lasted three hours
We watched the proceedings from the balcony

definitions: performing series of operations on data, especially by computer
preparing raw food or agricultural products for consumption or sale
subjecting materials to special treatment to alter their properties
examples: Data processing speeds have increased dramatically with new chips
The bank's processing center handles millions of transactions daily
Food processing plants must meet strict hygiene standards
Processing removes most nutrients from white flour
Ore processing extracts valuable metals from raw materials
The processing of recycled plastics requires specialized equipment

definitions: organized group of people walking formally in celebration, protest, or ritual
continuous line of people or vehicles moving forward in orderly fashion
examples: The funeral procession moved slowly through the streets
The wedding procession entered the church to organ music
A procession of trucks delivered supplies all morning
We watched the endless procession of tourists at the monument

definitions: hymn or piece of music sung or played during formal procession
formal entrance or march of participants in religious or ceremonial service
examples: The choir sang a traditional processional as clergy entered
The organist played a Bach processional for the ceremony
The processional included all graduating students and faculty
The bride chose a classical piece for her processional

definitions: central unit in computer that performs instructions and processes data
machine that processes food by chopping, mixing, or blending
person or company that processes raw materials or data
examples: The new processor runs twice as fast as the previous generation
Gaming computers require powerful graphics processors
The food processor quickly chopped all the vegetables
This processor can knead dough and grind meat
The payment processor handles all credit card transactions
Agricultural processors buy crops directly from farmers

definitions: public or official announcement dealing with matter of great importance
examples: The president issued a proclamation declaring a national emergency
The royal proclamation was read in every town square

definitions: action of delaying or postponing tasks despite knowing there will be negative consequences
examples: His procrastination resulted in missing the application deadline
Chronic procrastination can lead to stress and poor performance

definitions: biological process of producing offspring through sexual reproduction
examples: Many religions view procreation as a sacred duty
The survival of species depends on successful procreation

definitions: person who supervises students during an examination to prevent cheating
disciplinary officer at certain universities responsible for enforcing regulations
examples: The proctor collected all phones before the exam began
Two proctors monitored the testing room for irregularities
The university proctor investigated the dormitory incident
Oxford proctors have maintained order since medieval times

definitions: action of obtaining or procuring supplies, equipment, or services, especially for business or government
examples: The procurement department negotiates contracts with all suppliers
Government procurement must follow strict bidding procedures

definitions: pointed stick or rod used for poking or driving animals
act of poking or jabbing someone or something with finger or pointed object
reminder or encouragement to do something
examples: The farmer used a prod to guide cattle into the pen
Electric prods are controversial in animal handling
She gave him a prod with her elbow to get his attention
A gentle prod in the ribs woke him up
He needed a prod to finally start his homework
Sometimes we all need a prod to take action

definitions: person who spends money or resources freely and recklessly, often returning after wasteful absence
examples: The prodigal returned home after squandering his inheritance
Like the biblical prodigal, he sought forgiveness from his family

definitions: young person with exceptional qualities or abilities, especially in particular field
amazing or unusual thing, especially one out of the ordinary course of nature
examples: The chess prodigy defeated adult grandmasters at age ten
Mozart was a musical prodigy who composed at age five
The comet was regarded as a prodigy by ancient astronomers
Such athletic feats were considered prodigies of strength
